trans-unit.source: Learn how to scale your services Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to scale your services Azure.

trans-unit.source: Scale instance count manually or automatically
trans-unit.target: Scale instance count manually or automatically

trans-unit.source: In the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>, you can manually set the instance count of your service, or, you can set parameters to have it automatically scale based on demand.
trans-unit.target: In the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>, you can manually set the instance count of your service, or, you can set parameters to have it automatically scale based on demand.

trans-unit.source: This is typically referred to as Scale out or Scale in.
trans-unit.target: This is typically referred to as Scale out or Scale in.

trans-unit.source: Before scaling based on instance count, you should consider that scaling is affected by Pricing tier in addition to instance count.
trans-unit.target: Before scaling based on instance count, you should consider that scaling is affected by Pricing tier in addition to instance count.

trans-unit.source: Different pricing tiers can have different numbers cores and memory, and so they will have better performance for the same number of instances (which is Scale up or Scale down).
trans-unit.target: Different pricing tiers can have different numbers cores and memory, and so they will have better performance for the same number of instances (which is Scale up or Scale down).

trans-unit.source: This article specifically covers Scale in and out.
trans-unit.target: This article specifically covers Scale in and out.

trans-unit.source: You can scale in the portal, and you can also use the <link><linkText>REST API</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>.NET SDK</linkText><title></title></link> to adjust scale manually or automatically.
trans-unit.target: You can scale in the portal, and you can also use the <link><linkText>REST API</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>.NET SDK</linkText><title></title></link> to adjust scale manually or automatically.

trans-unit.source: Scaling manually
trans-unit.target: Scaling manually

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Portal, click Browse, then navigate to the resource you want to scale, such as a App Service plan.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Portal, click Browse, then navigate to the resource you want to scale, such as a App Service plan.

trans-unit.source: The Scale tile in Operations will tell you the status of scaling: Off for when you are scaling manually, On for when you are scaling by one or more performance metrics.
trans-unit.target: The Scale tile in Operations will tell you the status of scaling: Off for when you are scaling manually, On for when you are scaling by one or more performance metrics.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Scale tile</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Scale tile</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Clicking on the tile will take you to the Scale blade.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on the tile will take you to the Scale blade.

trans-unit.source: At the top of the scale blade you can see a history of autoscale actions the service.
trans-unit.target: At the top of the scale blade you can see a history of autoscale actions the service.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Scale blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Scale blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Only actions that are performed by autoscale will show up in this chart.
trans-unit.target: Only actions that are performed by autoscale will show up in this chart.

trans-unit.source: If you manually adjust the instance count, the change will not be reflected in this chart.
trans-unit.target: If you manually adjust the instance count, the change will not be reflected in this chart.

trans-unit.source: You can manually adjust the number Instances with slider.
trans-unit.target: You can manually adjust the number Instances with slider.

trans-unit.source: Click the Save command and you'll be scaled to that number of instances almost immediately.
trans-unit.target: Click the Save command and you'll be scaled to that number of instances almost immediately.

trans-unit.source: Scaling based on a pre-set metric
trans-unit.target: Scaling based on a pre-set metric

trans-unit.source: If you want the number of instances to automatically adjust based on a metric, select the metric you want in the Scale by dropdown.
trans-unit.target: If you want the number of instances to automatically adjust based on a metric, select the metric you want in the Scale by dropdown.

trans-unit.source: For example, for an App Service plan you can scale by CPU Percentage.
trans-unit.target: For example, for an App Service plan you can scale by CPU Percentage.

trans-unit.source: When you select a metric you'll get a slider, and/or, text boxes to enter the number of instances you want to scale between:
trans-unit.target: When you select a metric you'll get a slider, and/or, text boxes to enter the number of instances you want to scale between:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Scale blade with CPU Percentage</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Scale blade with CPU Percentage</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Autoscale will never take your service below or above the boundaries that you set, no matter your load.
trans-unit.target: Autoscale will never take your service below or above the boundaries that you set, no matter your load.

trans-unit.source: Second, you choose the target range for the metric.
trans-unit.target: Second, you choose the target range for the metric.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you chose CPU percentage, you can set a target for the average CPU across all of the instances in your service.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you chose CPU percentage, you can set a target for the average CPU across all of the instances in your service.

trans-unit.source: A scale out will happen when the average CPU exceeds the maximum you define, likewise, a scale in will happen whenever the average CPU drops below the minimum.
trans-unit.target: A scale out will happen when the average CPU exceeds the maximum you define, likewise, a scale in will happen whenever the average CPU drops below the minimum.

trans-unit.source: Click the Save command.
trans-unit.target: Click the Save command.

trans-unit.source: Autoscale will check every few minutes to make sure that you are in the instance range and target for your metric.
trans-unit.target: Autoscale will check every few minutes to make sure that you are in the instance range and target for your metric.

trans-unit.source: When your service receives additional traffic, you will get more instances without doing anything.
trans-unit.target: When your service receives additional traffic, you will get more instances without doing anything.

trans-unit.source: Scale based on other metrics
trans-unit.target: Scale based on other metrics

trans-unit.source: You can scale based on metrics other than the presets that appear in the Scale by dropdown, and can even have a complex set of scale out and scale in rules.
trans-unit.target: You can scale based on metrics other than the presets that appear in the Scale by dropdown, and can even have a complex set of scale out and scale in rules.

trans-unit.source: Adding or changing a rule
trans-unit.target: Adding or changing a rule

trans-unit.source: Choose the schedule and performance rules in the Scale by dropdown:
trans-unit.target: Choose the schedule and performance rules in the Scale by dropdown:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Performance rules</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Performance rules</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you previously had autoscale, on you'll see a view of the exact rules that you had.
trans-unit.target: If you previously had autoscale, on you'll see a view of the exact rules that you had.

trans-unit.source: To scale based on another metric click the Add Rule row.
trans-unit.target: To scale based on another metric click the Add Rule row.

trans-unit.source: You can also click one of the existing rows to change from the metric you previously had to the metric you want to scale by.
trans-unit.target: You can also click one of the existing rows to change from the metric you previously had to the metric you want to scale by.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add rule</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add rule</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Now you need to select which metric you want to scale by.
trans-unit.target: Now you need to select which metric you want to scale by.

trans-unit.source: When choosing a metric there are a couple things to consider:
trans-unit.target: When choosing a metric there are a couple things to consider:

trans-unit.source: The resource the metric comes from.
trans-unit.target: The resource the metric comes from.

trans-unit.source: Typically, this will be the same as the resource you are scaling.
trans-unit.target: Typically, this will be the same as the resource you are scaling.

trans-unit.source: However, if you want to scale by the depth of a Storage queue, the resource is the queue that you want to scale by.
trans-unit.target: However, if you want to scale by the depth of a Storage queue, the resource is the queue that you want to scale by.

trans-unit.source: The metric name itself.
trans-unit.target: The metric name itself.

trans-unit.source: The time aggregation of the metric.
trans-unit.target: The time aggregation of the metric.

trans-unit.source: This is how the data is combine over the duration.
trans-unit.target: This is how the data is combine over the duration.

trans-unit.source: After choosing your metric you choose the threshold for the metric, and the operator.
trans-unit.target: After choosing your metric you choose the threshold for the metric, and the operator.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could say Greater than 80%.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could say Greater than 80%.

trans-unit.source: Then choose the action that you want to take.
trans-unit.target: Then choose the action that you want to take.

trans-unit.source: There are a couple different type of actions:
trans-unit.target: There are a couple different type of actions:

trans-unit.source: Increase or decrease by - this will add or remove the Value number of instances you define
trans-unit.target: Increase or decrease by - this will add or remove the Value number of instances you define

trans-unit.source: Increase or decrease percent - this will change the instance count by a percent.
trans-unit.target: Increase or decrease percent - this will change the instance count by a percent.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could put 25 in the Value field, and if you currently had 8 instances, 2 would be added.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could put 25 in the Value field, and if you currently had 8 instances, 2 would be added.

trans-unit.source: Increase or decrease to - this will set the instance count to the Value you define.
trans-unit.target: Increase or decrease to - this will set the instance count to the Value you define.

trans-unit.source: Finally, you can choose cool down - how long this rule should wait after the previous scale action to scale again.
trans-unit.target: Finally, you can choose cool down - how long this rule should wait after the previous scale action to scale again.

trans-unit.source: After configuring your rule hit OK.
trans-unit.target: After configuring your rule hit OK.

trans-unit.source: Once you have configured all of the rules you want, be sure to hit the Save command.
trans-unit.target: Once you have configured all of the rules you want, be sure to hit the Save command.

trans-unit.source: Scaling with multiple steps
trans-unit.target: Scaling with multiple steps

trans-unit.source: The examples above are pretty basic.
trans-unit.target: The examples above are pretty basic.

trans-unit.source: However, if you want to be more agressive about scaling up (or down), you can even add multiple scale rules for the same metric.
trans-unit.target: However, if you want to be more agressive about scaling up (or down), you can even add multiple scale rules for the same metric.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can define two scale rules on CPU percentage:
trans-unit.target: For example, you can define two scale rules on CPU percentage:

trans-unit.source: Scale out by 1 instance if CPU percentage is above 60%
trans-unit.target: Scale out by 1 instance if CPU percentage is above 60%

trans-unit.source: Scale out by 3 instances if CPU percentage is above 85%
trans-unit.target: Scale out by 3 instances if CPU percentage is above 85%

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Multiple scale rules</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Multiple scale rules</linkText>

trans-unit.source: With this additional rule, if your load exceeds 85% before a scale action, you will get two additional instances instead of one.
trans-unit.target: With this additional rule, if your load exceeds 85% before a scale action, you will get two additional instances instead of one.

trans-unit.source: Scale based on a schedule
trans-unit.target: Scale based on a schedule

trans-unit.source: By default, when you create a scale rule it will always apply.
trans-unit.target: By default, when you create a scale rule it will always apply.

trans-unit.source: You can see that when you click on the profile header:
trans-unit.target: You can see that when you click on the profile header:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Profile</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Profile</linkText>

trans-unit.source: However, you may want to have more agressive scaling during the day, or the week, than on the weekend.
trans-unit.target: However, you may want to have more agressive scaling during the day, or the week, than on the weekend.

trans-unit.source: You could even shut down your service entirely off working hours.
trans-unit.target: You could even shut down your service entirely off working hours.

trans-unit.source: To do this, on the profile you have, select recurrence instead of always, and choose the times that you want the profile to apply.
trans-unit.target: To do this, on the profile you have, select recurrence instead of always, and choose the times that you want the profile to apply.

trans-unit.source: For example, to have a profile that applies during the week, in the Days dropdown uncheck Saturday and Sunday.
trans-unit.target: For example, to have a profile that applies during the week, in the Days dropdown uncheck Saturday and Sunday.

trans-unit.source: To have a profile that applies during the daytime, set the Start time to the time of day that you want to start at.
trans-unit.target: To have a profile that applies during the daytime, set the Start time to the time of day that you want to start at.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Default recurrence</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Default recurrence</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will need to add the profile that you want to apply at other times.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will need to add the profile that you want to apply at other times.

trans-unit.source: Click the Add Profile row.
trans-unit.target: Click the Add Profile row.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Off Work</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Off Work</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Name your new, second, profile, for example you could call it Off work.
trans-unit.target: Name your new, second, profile, for example you could call it Off work.

trans-unit.source: Then select recurrence again, and choose the instance count range you want during this time.
trans-unit.target: Then select recurrence again, and choose the instance count range you want during this time.

trans-unit.source: As with the Default profile, choose the Days you want this profile to apply to, and the Start time during the day.
trans-unit.target: As with the Default profile, choose the Days you want this profile to apply to, and the Start time during the day.

trans-unit.source: Autoscale will use the Daylight savings rules for whichever Time zone you select.
trans-unit.target: Autoscale will use the Daylight savings rules for whichever Time zone you select.

trans-unit.source: However, during Daylight savings time the UTC offset will show the base Time zone offset, not the Daylight savings UTC offset.
trans-unit.target: However, during Daylight savings time the UTC offset will show the base Time zone offset, not the Daylight savings UTC offset.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Now, you will need to add whatever rules you want to apply during your second profile.
trans-unit.target: Now, you will need to add whatever rules you want to apply during your second profile.

trans-unit.source: Click Add Rule, and then you could construct the same rule you have during the Default profile.
trans-unit.target: Click Add Rule, and then you could construct the same rule you have during the Default profile.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add rule to off work</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add rule to off work</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Be sure to create both a rule for scale out and scale in, or else during the profile the instance count will only grow (or decrease).
trans-unit.target: Be sure to create both a rule for scale out and scale in, or else during the profile the instance count will only grow (or decrease).

trans-unit.source: Finally, click Save.
trans-unit.target: Finally, click Save.
